facts.text: This is an appeal by special leave in an industrial matter.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave in an industrial matter.

facts.text: The appellant is a company carrying on the manufacture of textiles.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a companypany carrying on the manufacture of textiles.

facts.text: The respondent Kushal Bhan was in the employ of the company as a peon.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Kushal Bhan was in the employ of the companypany as a peon.

facts.text: The cycle of Ram Chandra, Head Clerk of the Folding Department was stolen on August 24, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the cycle of Ram Chandra, Head Clerk of the Folding Department was stolen on August 24, 1957.

facts.text: The matter was reported to the police.

anchor.surface_text: The matter was reported to the police.

facts.text: The cycle was recovered from the railway station cycle stand at the instance of the respondent who took the police there and picked out the stolen cycle from among 50/60 cycles standing there.

anchor.surface_text: Sometime later, the cycle was recovered from the railway station cycle stand at the instance of the respondent who took the police there and picked out the stolen cycle from among 50/60 cycles standing there.

facts.text: This matter was apparently brought to the notice of the company in October 1957.

anchor.surface_text: This matter was apparently brought to the numberice of the companypany in October 1957

facts.text: A charge-sheet was served on the respondent to the effect that he had stolen the cycle of Ram Chandra, Head Clerk, that it had been recovered at his instance and that a criminal case was pending against him with the police.

anchor.surface_text: and thereupon a charge-sheet was served on the respondent to the effect that he had stolen the cycle of Ram Chandra, Head Clerk, that it had been recovered at his instance and that a criminal case was pending against him with the police.

facts.text: The respondent was asked to show cause why he should not be dismissed for misconduct.

anchor.surface_text: He was asked to show cause why he should number be dismissed for misconduct.

facts.text: The respondent submitted his explanation on October 13, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent submitted his explanation on October 13, 1957.

facts.text: November 14, 1957, was fixed for enquiry as his explanation was unsatisfactory.

anchor.surface_text: As his explanation was unsatisfactory, November 14, 1957, was fixed for enquiry.

facts.text: The respondent appeared before the enquiry committee but stated that as the case was pending against him, he did not want to produce any defence till the matter was decided by the court.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent appeared before the enquiry companymitted but stated that as the case was pending against him, he did number want to produce any defence till the matter was decided by the companyrt.

facts.text: The respondent stated that he did not want to take part in the enquiry and was not prepared to give any answers to questions put to him.

anchor.surface_text: He further stated that he did number want to take part in the enquiry and was number prepared to give any answers to questions put to him.

facts.text: When questions were put to him at the enquiry he refused to answer them and eventually he left the place.

anchor.surface_text: When questions were put to him at the enquiry he refused to answer them and eventually he left the place.

facts.text: The company completed the enquiry and directed the dismissal of the respondent on the ground that the misconduct had been proved against him.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany, however, companypleted the enquiry and directed the dismissal of the respondent on the ground that the misconduct had been proved against him.

facts.text: An application was made under s. 33(2) of the Industrial Disputes Act, No. 14 of 1947, by the company to the tribunal for approval of the action taken against the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter an application was made under s. 33 2  of the Industrial Disputes Act, No. 14 of 1947, by the companypany to the tribunal for approval of the action taken against the respondent.

facts.text: The matter came before the tribunal on May 6, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The matter came before the tribunal on May 6, 1958.

facts.text: The respondent had been acquitted by the criminal court on April 8, 1958, on the ground that the case against him was not free from doubt.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime, the respondent had been acquitted by the criminal companyrt on April 8, 1958, on the ground that the case against him was number free from doubt.

facts.text: The copy of the judgment of the criminal court was produced before the tribunal and it refused to approve the order of dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: The companyy of the judgment of the criminal companyrt was produced before the tribunal and it refused to approve the order of dismissal.

facts.text: The company thereupon applied for special leave to this Court resulting in the present appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany thereupon applied for special leave to this Court resulting in the present appeal.

facts.text: The tribunal refused to grant approval under s. 33(2) of the Industrial Disputes Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that this was a case in which the tribunal patently erred in number granting approval under s. 33 2  of the Industrial Disputes Act.

facts.text: The Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside the order of the tribunal and granted approval to the order of dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal and setting aside the order of the tribunal grant approval to the order of the appellant dismissing the respondent.
Thereafter an application was made under s. 33 2  of the Industrial Disputes Act, No. 14 of 1947, by the companypany to the tribunal for approval of the action taken against the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: Learned companynsel for the respondent, on the other hand, urges that principles of natural justice require that an employer should wait at least for the decision of the criminal trial companyrt before taking disciplinary action,

It is true that very often employers stay enquiries pending the decision of the criminal trial companyrts and that is fair but we cannot say that principles of natural justice require that an employer must wait for the decision at least of the criminal trial companyrt before taking action against the employee. In Shri Bimal Kanta Mukherjee v. Messrs. Newsmans Printing Works   1956  L.A.C. 188 , this was the view taken by the Labour Appellant Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave in an industrial matter.
The companypany thereupon applied for special leave to this Court resulting in the present appeal.

issues.text: Whether principles of natural justice require that an employer must wait for the decision of the criminal trial court before taking disciplinary action against the employee

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the respondent, on the other hand, urges that principles of natural justice require that an employer should wait at least for the decision of the criminal trial court before taking disciplinary action,

issues.text: Whether there was a failure of natural justice in the domestic enquiry conducted by the employer

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances, there was in our opinion no failure of natural justice in this case and if the respondent did not choose to take part in the enquiry no fault can be found with that enquiry.

issues.text: Whether the tribunal patently erred in not granting approval under Section 33(2) of the Industrial Disputes Act

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that this was a case in which the tribunal patently erred in not granting approval under s. 33 2  of the Industrial Disputes Act.

issues.text: Whether the tribunal completely lost sight of the limits of its jurisdiction under Section 33(2) of the Industrial Disputes Act

anchor.surface_text: Besides it is apparent that in making the order under appeal, the tribunal has completely lost sight of the limits of its jurisdiction under s. 33 2 .

arguments.claim: The company was not bound to wait for the result of the trial in the criminal court and it could, and did, hold a fair enquiry against the respondent, and if the respondent refused to participate in it and left the place where the enquiry was being held, the company could do no more than to complete it and come to such conclusion as was possible on the evidence before it.

anchor.surface_text: The main contention on behalf of the appellant-company is that the company was not bound to wait for the result of the trial in the criminal court and that it could, and did, hold a fair enquiry against the respondent, and if the respondent refused to participate in it and left the place where the enquiry was being held, the company could do no more than to complete it and come to such conclusion as was possible on the evidence before it.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: nyclusion as was possible on the evidence before it. Learned companynsel for the respondent, on the other hand, urges that principles of natural justi

arguments.court_reasoning: Court held that natural justice does not require waiting for criminal decision and enquiry was fair despite employee's refusal to participate

arguments.claim: Principles of natural justice require that an employer should wait at least for the decision of the criminal trial court before taking disciplinary action, and that inasmuch as the employer did not do so the employee was justified in not taking part in the disciplinary proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the respondent, on the other hand, urges that principles of natural justice require that an employer should wait at least for the decision of the criminal trial court before taking disciplinary action, and that inasmuch as the employer did not do so in this case the employee was justified in not taking part in the disciplinary proceedings which dealt with the very same matter which was the subject-matter of trial in the criminal court.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: nyclusion as was possible on the evidence before it. Learned companynsel for the respondent, on the other hand, urges that principles of natural justi

arguments.court_reasoning: Court stated it is fair but not required by natural justice; cited precedent; this case simple nature

arguments.claim: Principles of natural justice do not require that an employer must wait for the decision of the criminal trial court before taking action against the employee.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that very often employers stay enquiries pending the decision of the criminal trial courts and that is fair but we cannot say that principles of natural justice require that an employer must wait for the decision at least of the criminal trial court before taking action against the employee. In Shri Bimal Kanta Mukherjee v. Messrs. Newsmans Printing Works 1956 L.A.C. 188 , this was the view taken by the Labour Appellant Tribunal.

arguments.qualifiers: It is true that very often... and that is fair but

arguments.claim: If the case is of a grave nature or involves questions of fact or law, which are not simple, it would be advisable for the employer to await the decision of the trial court.

anchor.surface_text: We may, however, add that if the case is of a grave nature or involves questions of fact or law, which are not simple, it would be advisable for the employer to await the decision of the trial court, so that the defence of the employee in the criminal case may not be prejudiced. The present, however, is a case of a very simple nature and so the employer cannot be blamed for the course adopted by him.

arguments.claim: There was no failure of natural justice in this case and if the respondent did not choose to take part in the enquiry no fault can be found with that enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances, there was in our opinion no failure of natural justice in this case and if the respondent did not choose to take part in the enquiry no fault can be found with that enquiry.

arguments.claim: This was a case in which the tribunal patently erred in not granting approval under s. 33(2) of the Industrial Disputes Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that this was a case in which the tribunal patently erred in not granting approval under s. 33(2) of the Industrial Disputes Act.

arguments.claim: In making the order under appeal, the tribunal has completely lost sight of the limits of its jurisdiction under s. 33(2).

anchor.surface_text: Besides it is apparent that in making the order under appeal, the tribunal has completely lost sight of the limits of its jurisdiction under s. 33(2).

holdings.text: principles of natural justice require that an employer must wait for the decision at least of the criminal trial court before taking action against the employee

anchor.surface_text: It is true that very often employers stay enquiries pending the decision of the criminal trial courts and that is fair but we cannot say that principles of natural justice require that an employer must wait for the decision at least of the criminal trial court before taking action against the employee. In Shri Bimal Kanta Mukherjee v. Messrs. Newsmans Printing Works   1956  L.A.C. 188 , this was the view taken by the Labour Appellant Tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fair practice to await criminal decision often but not mandated by natural justice; follows precedent from Labour Appellate Tribunal in Shri Bimal Kanta Mukherjee case

holdings.text: if the case is of a grave nature or involves questions of fact or law, which are not simple, it would be advisable for the employer to await the decision of the trial court

anchor.surface_text: We may, however, add that if the case is of a grave nature or involves questions of fact or law, which are not simple, it would be advisable for the employer to await the decision of the trial court, so that the defence of the employee in the criminal case may not be prejudiced. The present, however, is a case of a very simple nature and so the employer cannot be blamed for the course adopted by him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Advisory for complex cases to avoid prejudicing employee's criminal defence; obiter as hypothetical and distinguished from present simple case

holdings.text: there was in our opinion no failure of natural justice in this case and if the respondent did not choose to take part in the enquiry no fault can be found with that enquiry

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances, there was in our opinion no failure of natural justice in this case and if the respondent did not choose to take part in the enquiry no fault can be found with that enquiry.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Enquiry fair and opportunity provided; employee's voluntary refusal to participate does not vitiate it

holdings.text: this was a case in which the tribunal patently erred in not granting approval under s. 33(2) of the Industrial Disputes Act

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that this was a case in which the tribunal patently erred in not granting approval under s. 33(2) of the Industrial Disputes Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Domestic enquiry fair and misconduct proved despite acquittal; tribunal wrongly refused approval

holdings.text: in making the order under appeal, the tribunal has completely lost sight of the limits of its jurisdiction under s. 33(2)

anchor.surface_text: Besides it is apparent that in making the order under appeal, the tribunal has completely lost sight of the limits of its jurisdiction under s. 33(2).

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal exceeded by re-appreciating evidence like criminal court instead of checking enquiry fairness

holdings.text: We therefore allow the appeal and setting aside the order of the tribunal grant approval to the order of the appellant dismissing the respondent

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal and setting aside the order of the tribunal grant approval to the order of the appellant dismissing the respondent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appeal succeeds on grounds of fair enquiry, no natural justice violation, and tribunal error under s.33(2)

The present, however, is a case of a very simple nature and so the employer cannot be blamed for the course adopted by him.
